title: Navi SDE 1 | Leadsquared SDE-2 offer
content:
giving back to the community guys!!

Tier 1, 2.5 yoe. 

Current CTC | SDE-1: 
19LPA, 2.5 (1.5L first year + 1L second year joining bonus)

Leadsquared | SDE-2:
25.5LPA, 2L on completion of 18 months. 
(esops are only given in leadship roles told by the HR)

Navi | SDE-1:
27LPA, 2L joining bonus, 5.4L esops(4yrs vesting)

Navi was about to lowball and i mean it makes sense for them to offer me ~20-30% hike on my current CTC; but because of the competing offer from Leadsquared I got this generous offer. Still its far less than what it gave in my college 2 years back. 

benefits at Navi are superb. You get food all 7 days at the company for 4 times each day and food options are very very good, I am loving the food here and the work culture is not that bad, though I havent worked for a long time and just started working but still I feel like people are superb and helpful. you will definitley get to learn a hell lot. 

Anyways, I would be most probably leaving Navi as I got a job at much bigger firm which is best in class in what it does and is upto the similar levels of MAANG.

Keep hustling and uplift others. They may get ahead of you nevertheless you would feel good that you enabled them and the feeling is incredible man! I feel so much happy and content after helping my friends by letting them know the minute details of the preparation.

title: Cashfree Payments Interview Experience | SDE-2 | Rejected
content:
## Background :
- Experience: 3+ years
- Current Role: Software Engineer 2 @ Unicorn Startup
- Current CTC: ₹18 LPA (Fixed) + 10% Annual Bonus
- Cashfree Payments Offer: ₹30 LPA CTC

---

## How It Started
Recruiter found my profile on Naukri, mailed me, and scheduled the interviews after my profile got shortlisted.

---

## 
The interviewer asked a coding question related to Merge Intervals.

Problem statement:

- Multiple celebrities have given their available time slots.
You need to find a common time interval when all celebrities can meet.

- Tested skills in:

    - Interval merging logic
    - Sorting and boundary handling
    - Time and space complexity discussion

✅ Completed the solution and discussed optimizations.

---

## Round 2 – LLD Round

- Task: Design an **Online Parking Lot System**

- Core functionalities:
    - Search available parking slots
    - Book / Reserve a slot

I covered class design, relationships, and flow diagrams.

The interviewer wanted a more refined approach for the search functionality, and while I justified my design choices, they expected a different perspective.

---

## Outcome

Got an update 2 days later that they decided not to move forward for this role.

Overall, it was a short and structured process, mainly testing problem-solving and object-oriented design depth.

---

title: JPMC | JP Morgon | Cohort Hiring | SWE 3 | Rejected
content:
All happened in October.
Compensation : 40 LPA Fixed

I applied to on of the positions on their Job portal.

# OA
Q1: Minimum operations to make the 2nd half of the string an anagram of the first half. swapping 1 character with another is 1 operation.
Q2: Given queries as [L,R], flip the sign of all the elements of array from L to R. Return the array at the end.

After this got call for cohort hiring and all 3 round will happen back to back.


# Coding+Code review round
Code Review a piece of code: There were a few APIs and you need to review it - check variable names, exception handling, using enums, reusing common code, synchronization and locking etc
Coding : Problem (telephone circular dial)

You have a circular dial with digits 0,1,2,...,9 arranged in that order around the circle. The dial’s pointer starts at 0. You are given a string s of digits (for example "8053") that you must dial in order.

You may rotate the pointer clockwise or counterclockwise. Moving the pointer by one position (to an adjacent digit) costs 1.

Optionally, pressing a digit might cost 1 (if the problem counts presses). I'll show both variants: rotation cost only and rotation + press cost.

Return the minimum total cost to input the whole string.


# HLD Round
Asked to design a Rate Limiter
Got into an agrument in this, during requirement i had said I will implement the sliding window counter method (which will be an approximation) as I dont think the rate limiting needs to be completele accurate.
But during designing that, she started saying read the question again (which didnt mention anyting strict as requirement) I said the same no such thing is mentioned and I explained already my assumptions during requirement, Anyway I said if we want it to be strict we will need a sliding window log method which will use memory.



# Behavior Round
Several questions regarding my project and how i handled this and that etc.


# Verdict: Rejected (probably)
Never got an update after the interviews. and the HR never picked my call again. HR never shared his email and communication happened over jpmc system generated mails.

title: Groww SDE intern Interview Experience ( AI/LLM ) role | 6 month
content:
Hi all,
Just sharing my interview experience hope it helps someone preparing for Groww interviews! 

# How I got the opportunity 

I was referred by an employee at Groww and got the interview call directly after sharing my resume. All the rounds on same day.

# Round 1 — DSA (1 hour) 

The round focused on core data structures and algorithms, with two LeetCode easy–medium problems:

1.Single Element in an Array
2.Container With Most Water

I started with brute-force solutions, then walked through optimized approaches for both.
After solving, the interviewer briefly discussed my projects. Overall, the round went well.

# Round 2 — DSA + AI (1 hour, back-to-back)

The first half was a deep discussion around my AI/GenAI projects and understanding of LLMs — mainly to check my interest and knowledge.

In the second half, I was given a design-style problem, not typical DSA.
The task was to form pairs (3 girls and 2 boys) based on certain priorities, and I had to write pseudocode and explain my reasoning.

The round went fine overall.

# HR Round

An HR round was planned, but just before it started, I was informed that the feedback wasn’t positive, so it didn’t happen.


# Final Thoughts

Although I didn’t move forward, it was a great learning experience. My knowledge in AI/ML wasn’t very strong, that might have affected the feedback.

# Compensation:
Stipend - 61k
CTC - 20-24 LPA

title: Wayfair Interview Experience | SDE 2 | Selected
content:
## Background :

- Experience: 3+ years
- Current Role: Software Engineer 2 @ Unicorn Startup
- Current CTC: ₹18 LPA (Fixed) + 10% Annual Bonus
- Wayfair Offer: ₹32 LPA Fixed + ₹1.92L PF (Total ₹33.92 LPA)

---

## How It Started

Got contacted by a recruiter from Instahyre who shared an overview of the role and compensation details. The process started quickly after I confirmed my interest.

---

## Online Assessment (Hackerrank)

- Consisted of 2 mid-to-hard LeetCode-style questions.
- Difficulty was moderate to high — focused on problem-solving and edge case handling.

✅ Cleared and moved to the next round.

---

## Round 1 – Design Round (Hackerrank Platform)

Task: Design an Order Management System.

- Some classes and interfaces were already provided; I had to implement the missing functionalities.
- After completing the code, there was a follow-up discussion on approach, design decisions, and complexity.

---

## Round 2 – Application Design Round

- Asked to design a Bike Rental System.
- Focus areas:
    - API Design
    - Database Schema Design
    - Sequence Diagram / Flow Explanation

- Additional SQL queries were asked:
    - Fetch available vehicles
    - Fetch booked vehicles
    - Identify overdue rentals
    
✅ Cleared this round and got invited for onsite.

---

## Round 3 – Onsite Interviews

(Conducted with multiple engineering managers)

**1️⃣ Hiring Manager (Engineering Manager) – 45 mins**

- Discussion around:
    - Current project & responsibilities
    - Resume-based technical questions
    - Spring Boot concepts (Beans, Transactions, REST design)
    - Deployment strategies and scaling practices

**2️⃣ Senior Engineering Manager – 15 mins**

- Short round covering:
    -  “Why Wayfair?”
    - How I handle challenges, deadlines, and team collaboration.

---

## Round 4 – HR Discussion (30 mins)

- Salary discussion
- Cultural fitment and general behavioral questions

---

## Additional Round

About a week later, HR informed me that the original position got closed, but they wanted to consider me for another team.
They scheduled one more discussion (1 hour) with another Hiring Manager, which included:
- Deep dive into my current project
- Discussion on database design choices and reasoning

---

## Outcome

Although the process took some time due to internal changes, the overall experience with Wayfair was structured and professional.
They focused heavily on design skills, clean architecture thinking, and real-world application knowledge.

---

title: Locus Interview Experience | SDE 2 | Selected
content:
## Background :

- Experience: 3+ years
- Current Role: Software Engineer 2 @ Unicorn Startup
- Current CTC: ₹18 LPA (Fixed) + 10% Annual Bonus
- Locus Offer: ₹24 LPA Fixed + ₹1L Joining Bonus

---

## How It Started

Got contacted by a recruiter from Instahyre who shared an overview of the role and compensation details. The process started quickly after I confirmed my interest.

---

## Round 1 – Online Assessment

This round had 2 questions:

### 1. DSA + LLD Hybrid Question:
- Asked to design a Bank System with different functionalities.
- The problem had 4 stages — after you pass all test cases of one stage, the next part unlocks.
- It tested both coding ability and design thinking.

### 2. System Design Case Study:

- A detailed design statement was given, followed by 16 MCQs based on that statement.
- It checked understanding of scalability, consistency, database choice, and API design concepts.

✅ Got a call from HR the next day that I cleared this round.

---

## Round 2 – HR / Culture Fit (30 mins)

Mostly around behavioral and cultural alignment.
Topics like: why Locus, current role challenges, and expectations.

---

## Round 3 – System Design (1 hr 30 mins)

With a **Senior Engineering Manager.**

- Design a Flash Sale System (similar to Flipkart’s Big Billion Days).
- Discussion included topics like:
    - Rate limiting
    - Cache usage
    - Handling inventory consistency
    - Queue-based order processing
    - Scaling under heavy load
    - DB Choices

---

## Round 4 – Discussion with VP of Engineering (45 mins)

- Deep discussion around my past projects and one side project I had worked on.
- Interestingly, he was building something similar — so we had an engaging technical discussion.
---

## Outcome

All rounds were completed in a single day, and I received the offer the same evening 🎉
Overall, the experience was smooth, fast-paced, and very professional.
Locus has a well-structured process that tests both technical depth and system design understanding.

---

title: SDE 1 Spinny (Gurugram) | Backend Engineer
content:
Hey everyone 👋
I recently received a Backend Engineer offer (12 LPA) from Spinny, Gurugram, and wanted to share my interview experience — especially for folks from Tier 3 colleges looking to break into good product companies.

🧠 Background

🎓 College: Tier 3 (CSE)

💼 Experience: 1 year internship at a travel-tech company (worked on backend APIs, Spring Boot, AWS, Redis, SQL)

💰 Offer: Backend Engineer – 12 LPA (CTC)

🧩 Interview Process

👉 Round 1 – DSA (Tree-based questions)

Conducted by Interview Vector

Two medium-level coding problems, both on Tree data structures

Q1: Construct Binary Tree from Traversals

Q2: Lowest Common Ancestor / Boundary Traversal (type)

Time: 60 mins

Tip: Practice standard tree problems — recursion and iterative traversals

👉 Round 2 – System Design (Splitwise)

Asked to design Splitwise

Focus on:

Class design (User, Expense, Group)

How to calculate balances efficiently

Data consistency and scalability considerations

Also discussed REST API endpoints and DB schema

Tip: Focus on how you’d scale and handle concurrency

👉 Round 3 – Managerial Round (DSA + Discussion)

Asked to implement HashMap (core logic and collision handling)

Discussion around project ownership, debugging approach, and teamwork

Tip: Be ready to explain internal workings of collections

👉 Round 4 – VP Round (Project + SQL)

Deep dive into projects — architecture, challenges, impact

SQL questions on joins, aggregation, and optimizing queries

Also discussed cloud exposure (AWS, caching, monitoring)

🧰 Tech Stack Used

Java, Spring Boot, MySQL, Redis, AWS, JUnit, RestAssured

📚 Preparation Strategy

DSA: 150+ LeetCode problems (Trees, Graphs, DP)

System Design: Watched videos from CodeKarle, Gaurav Sen

Java Fundamentals: Collections, Multithreading, JVM basics

Projects: Focused on scalability & data flow explanation

💡 Key Takeaways

Tree questions are very common for backend interviews — revise traversals & recursion

Keep one strong project you can explain end-to-end

Be clear on how you design APIs and databases — even for small systems

Confidence & communication matter as much as coding

title: Kotak Mahindra Bank SDE-2 Vs Nykaa SDE-2 || Fintech vs Ecommerce
content:
Hi guys,

I'm reaching out to the experts and professionals, seeking their advice and suggestion.

I have been offered SDE-2 Role by both Kotak Mahindra Bank and Nykaa, both are Bangalore Location 

**Nykaa** 

- CTC: 30LPA BASE + 10% varible [3LPA] = 33 LPA
- 5 days WFO with strict 8.5hrs
- No benefits apart from CTC
- 6 month probabtion period
- 2months notice period
- I have joined Nykaa last week only, the team seems to be chill and life seems to be less stressful compared to KMB
- Some reviews of collegues state that the 8.5hrs is a negativr but since he's able to complete all work within this time, so there's good WL Balance & Boundary. 

**Kotak Mahindra Bank**
- 32LPA + 10% Variable(3.2lpa) = 35.2 LPA
- Offer is still under discussion but mostly aligned with above figures as per initial discussion 
- Decent benefits
- 3-4 days WFO, Rest is WFH = Hybrid Policy
- 3months notice period 
- 3months probation period 
- Since it's a Fintech firm so work is quite Chaotic according to collegues/interviewers. Everything is P0, and has lots of stress just like Amazon. Since, most of KMB employees in abovr hierarchy as ex Amazon employees
- Every Wednesday and Friday has deployment at 1Am and monitoring till 4am
- A lot of amazon like processes and PIP processes.







I feel like at Nykaa, given their decent pace and longer probation, I'll be able to grow at a steady pace without any headache, ensuring good personal & professional growth. On the contrary, I feel like although at KMB, I will be under constant stress, but if I'll be able to sustain that  pressure then I will learn a lot in this fast paced fintech environment, which has it's own value. I am very much confused right now, what to choose.


I request the experts here to guide me to the right path.


Looking forward to all of your guidances.Let me kniw if any further information is required . Thanks in advance.

**Round 1: Coding Test (Online Assessment)**

> The coding test was conducted on Accolite’s internal assessment platform.
To be honest, the platform was quite laggy and not very user-friendly, which made the test experience a bit frustrating.

- The coding question was similar to finding the Lowest Common Ancestor in a Binary Search Tree (BST).

- The tricky part was that we had to write JUnit test cases for our code as well. Because of the laggy interface, most of the time went into handling the platform rather than optimizing the code.

- There were also some MCQs, but I could attempt only a few due to time constraints.

*🧠 Tip: Focus on easy to easy–medium level DSA questions and get comfortable with JUnit test cases. Time management is key since the platform can be slow.*

---


**Round 2: Technical Interview**

- This round mainly focused on Java 8 and advanced Java concepts.

- The interviewer gave one coding problem and asked me to solve it strictly using Java 8 features (Streams, Lambdas, Optionals, etc.).

- The problem itself was not hard, but they wanted to see how effectively I could apply modern Java concepts.

- A few additional questions came from Multithreading and Spring Boot basics.

*🧩 Tip: Revise Streams API, Functional Interfaces, Collectors, and core Spring Boot annotations. They focus more on your coding approach than just the final output.*

---

**Round 3: Techno-Managerial Interview (Approx. 1.5 Hours)**

> This was the most detailed round of the entire process, and during this round, I got to know that the position was actually for Goldman Sachs as the client.

**First Half (Technical):**

- Deep dive into Spring Boot, Microservices, REST APIs, API Gateway, Deployment process, and CI/CD pipelines.

- Questions were scenario-based and tested how I would approach real-world issues like service failures, scalability, and versioning.

**Second Half (Managerial):**

- Detailed discussion on my current project, roles and responsibilities, and features I delivered.

- I was asked about story points assigned in the last sprint and how much I delivered on time.

- The focus was on accountability, communication, and ownership of work.

*🧠 Tip: Have a strong understanding of your project especially architecture, deployment flow, and your personal contributions.*

---

**Round 4: HR Discussion (Approx. 30 Minutes)**

> This was a very calm and straightforward discussion.

- Covered salary expectations, family background, and preferred work mode.

- We also talked about benefits and allowances, make sure you ask clearly about:

  - Joining bonus

  - Relocation allowance

  - Temporary stay/accommodation support

*💡 Tip: If you are expecting a 150%+ hike, prepare a clear justification for it, like your technical expertise, project ownership, or market standards.*

---

title: 🏆 LeetCode Ultimate Hack Sheet | Quick Reference for Everyone
content:
Hey friends 
I put together a **compact hack sheet** that’s useful for everyone from beginners to advanced coders. It covers key patterns, templates, and tips that **actually help in interviews & contests**.  

---

## 1️⃣ Problem Patterns & Templates

| Pattern | Common Problem Types | Quick Tip / Template |
|---------|-------------------|--------------------|
| **Two Pointers** | Sorted arrays, pairs, triplets, palindrome substring | Use Left & Right pointers → move based on condition |
| **Sliding Window** | Substrings, max/min sums, consecutive elements | Window can be fixed or dynamic → maintain count/frequency |
| **HashMap / Frequency Counting** | Subarray sum, duplicate detection | Track counts → check conditions quickly |
| **Prefix Sum** | Range sums, cumulative sums | `prefix[i] = prefix[i-1] + nums[i]` → get sum in O(1) |
| **Binary Search** | Search, insert position, rotated array | Set `low, high`, compute `mid = (low+high)//2` |
| **DFS / BFS** | Tree, Graph, Maze, Island problems | DFS → recursion/stack, BFS → queue |
| **Dynamic Programming** | Subsequence, knapsack, matrix, paths | Identify state, relation, base case → memoize results |
| **Backtracking** | Combinations, permutations | Choose / Not choose → build recursion tree |
| **Greedy** | Interval scheduling, max profit | Sort & pick the optimal choice at each step |

> **Tip:** Master one pattern → 90% of similar problems become much easier!

---

## 2️⃣ Top 50 Must-Do Problems

- **Array / Strings**: Two Sum, Trapping Rain Water, Subarray Sum Equals K, Longest Substring Without Repeating Characters  
- **Linked List**: Reverse Linked List, Merge Two Sorted Lists, Linked List Cycle  
- **Tree / Graph**: Maximum Depth of Binary Tree, Binary Tree Level Order, Number of Islands  
- **DP**: Climbing Stairs, Coin Change, Longest Increasing Subsequence, Minimum Path Sum  
- **Sliding Window / Two Pointers**: Minimum Window Substring, 3Sum, Container With Most Water  
- **Heap / Priority Queue**: Merge K Sorted Lists, Top K Frequent Elements  

> **Pro Tip:** Focus on **patterns**, not just problem titles.

---


## 3️⃣ Code Snippet Templates

**Binary Search**
```python
def binary_search(arr, target):
    low, high = 0, len(arr)-1
    while low <= high:
        mid = (low + high)//2
        if arr[mid] == target:
            return mid
        elif arr[mid] < target:
            low = mid + 1
        else:
            high = mid - 1
    return -1
```
**Sliding Window**
```python
left = 0
for right in range(len(nums)):
    while condition_not_met:
        left += 1

```
**DFS**
```python
def dfs(node):
    if not node: return
    dfs(node.left)
    dfs(node.right)

```
## 4️⃣ Common Tricks

- Modulus & Remainder → for cycles & wrapping arrays
- Sorting → simplifies Two-Pointer & Greedy problems
- HashMap → reduces nested loops, fast lookup
- Edge Cases First → empty array, single element, negative numbers
- Explain Aloud → helps retain patterns

## 5️⃣ Interview Mindset Hacks

- Patterns > Memorization
- Solve 1 problem in 2 ways → brute + optimized
- Use LeetCode Discuss for alternate solutions after attempting
- Track progress → Easy → Medium → Hard
- Time yourself → simulate interview conditions

💡 **Extra Hack:** Make your personal cheat sheet with patterns + go-to snippets + top 10 problems → for last-minute revision.

![please-upvote-and.jpg](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/b874ec98-a526-493b-8d91-4dad79d6d6e5_1759915939.921822.jpeg)

title: Freecine Video Recommendation Engine | System Design
content:
# Problem Statement

Design and implement the core logic for a video recommendation engine used in [Freecine](https://frecine.com.br/).
![8fc07d86-16f6-4767-9c97-4e4cd498135c.png](https://assets.leetcode.com/users/images/0571b6b6-221b-4c20-9488-51ea4d7ed934_1759156124.547871.png)


The engine should suggest videos as the user interacts with the platform, based on previous watch history, popularity, and user preferences.

Given a search query or recently watched video, the engine should return top recommended titles (e.g., related movies, trending series, or popular APK content).

Recommendations should be ranked either by frequency of views or relevance to user interests.

We will use the strategy pattern to allow ranking logic based on different strategies.

# Implementation

User Context – each user has a history of watched videos, genres, and languages.

Recommendation Engine – fetches related videos from the library.

Ranking Strategies – based on frequency (most watched) or relevance (genre + language match).

Updating Usage – each time a video is played, its view count should be updated in the system.

# Entities

- VideoNode (data structure to store videos & traverse by category/genre)

- Context → language (e.g., English, Portuguese, Spanish) + genre (Action, Anime, Drama)

- VideoEntry → metadata and details about each video

- EntityType (Enum) → MOVIE, SERIES, ANIME, DOCUMENTARY, LIVE

- RankStrategy → rankVideos(List availableVideos, String query)

FrequencyBased

RelevanceBased

RecommendationEngine (Facade class)

# Entity Fields

- VideoNode

- children

- isEndOfVideo

- viewCount

- videoTitle

# entityType

- language

# Methods

- insertVideo(String videoTitle)

- findVideo(String videoTitle)

- getRecommendations(String prefix/query)

- deleteVideo()

# VideoEntry

- videoTitle

- entryType

- language

- viewCount

# RecommendationEngine

- VideoNode

- RankStrategy

- currentLanguage

- contextHistory

# Methods
- addVideo()

- recommend()

- recordView()

- initializeLanguage()

title: Interview Experience at Inflection.io | Software Engineer II
content:
# Online Assessment (OA)

1. Write a Python program to make a GET request to an API that returns a nested JSON string. The task was to recursively sort all internal dictionaries, remove duplicates, and filter out null or empty values.

2. Debug a piece of code by identifying and fixing logical errors.

# Technical Interview (Low-Level Design + Resume Discussion)

- Detailed discussion about my resume and previous backend projects.

- Design a system to support CPU scheduling algorithms such as FCFS, Round Robin, and Priority Scheduling.

- Emphasis on clean class design, abstraction, extensibility, queues, and strategy pattern.

- The interviewer was collaborative and focused on my thought process and design clarity.
# Behavioral / Culture-Fit Round

Sample questions included:

- If you could design your ideal programming language by mixing features from any languages you like, what characteristics or features would it have and why?

- If you had to give a talk unprepared, which topic would you choose?

- Also covered motivation, learning approach, and communication style.

# HR / Offer Discussion

- Final discussion on compensation, hybrid work model, and joining timeline.

# Offer & Compensation:

- Base Salary: ₹24,00,000

- Equity / ESOPs: ₹17,00,000 (at time of offer)

- Total Compensation: Approximately ₹41,00,000

- Work Model: Hybrid (office in Bangalore)

title: Sandvine  (Applogic networks)  | Feedback  🚩| Bangalore India |
content:
If you're a fresher, Sandvine might be worth considering to get your foot in the door. The pay (16–17 LPA CTC) is decent for 0–2 YOE folks, but don’t expect great learning or cutting-edge work. Treat it as a stepping stone—learn on your own and plan to move on after a year or two.

**However, for senior engineers — think twice:**

🚫 Culture & Learning: Stagnant. No real tech growth, outdated stack. Senior folks who've been here for 7+ years are sitting comfortably with high salaries while expecting mid-level engineers to grind for peanuts.

🎭 HR Tactics: HR will try to lowball and fear-monger. Be firm and negotiate hard. Don’t fall for the "great exposure & learning" pitch — it's mostly fluff.

🕒 WLB: Mixed bag. It’s not terrible, but not great either. Many folks regularly stay late. don’t expect a clear boundary between work and personal life.

**SKIP IT. THERE ARE FAR BETTER PLACES FOR SKILLED ENGINEERS.**
